description: Take minimal prime q such that n(q+1)-1 is prime (A060324), that is, the smallest prime q so that n = (p+1)/(q+1) with p prime; sequence gives values of p.
comments: A conjecture of Schinzel, if true, would imply that such a p always exists.
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..10000
Matthew M. Conroy, A sequence related to a conjecture of Schinzel, J. Integ. Seqs. Vol. 4 (2001), #01.1.7.
Peter Luschny, Schinzel-Sierpinski conjecture and Calkin-Wilf tree.
A. Schinzel and W. Sierpiński, Sur certaines hypotheses concernant les nombres premiers, Acta Arithmetica 4 (1958), 185-208; erratum 5 (1958) p. 259.
maple: a:= proc(n) local q;       q:= 2;       while not isprime(n*(q+1)-1) do          q:= nextprime(q);       od; n*(q+1)-1    end:seq(a(n), n=1..300);
mathematica: a[n_] := (q = 2; While[ ! PrimeQ[n*(q+1)-1], q = NextPrime[q]]; n*(q+1)-1); Table[a[n], {n, 1, 57}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Feb 17 2012, after Maple *)
crossrefs: Cf. A060424. Values of q are given in A060324.
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Jul 01, 2001
